edge: Tommy Wiseau originally wrote The Room as a play in 2001, after seeing the film The Talented Mr. Ripley.
He then adapted the play into a 540-page book, which he was unable to get published.
Wiseau decided to adapt the play into a film, producing it himself in order to maintain creative control.
According to The Disaster Artist (Greg Sestero's book based on the making of The Room), Wiseau was already independently wealthy at the time production began.
He claims to have amassed a fortune through entrepreneurship and real estate development in Los Angeles and San Francisco, a story Sestero found impossible to believe.
Wiseau spent the entire US$6,000,000 (equivalent to about $9,900,000 in 2023) budget for The Room on production and marketing;
According to Sestero, Wiseau made numerous poor decisions during filming that resulted in high marketing costs.
Many members of the cast and crew had to be replaced.
Wiseau's poor decisions during filming, such as building sets and purchasing equipment instead of renting, resulted in inflated costs.
Many members of the cast and crew had to be replaced due to unknown reasons.
Wiseau's poor decisions during filming caused high production costs.
Wiseau selected actors from thousands of head shots for the film.
Sestero wrote, produced, and starred in the independent drama The Room.
Wiseau was a co-star, co-writer, and co-producer of the film, alongside Sestero.
Most of the cast had limited film experience prior to working on The Room.
friendship between Sestero and Wiseau before production began

Danielle was originally cast as Michelle but was given the Lisa role when the original actress was dismissed because her 'personality... didn't seem to fit'

In a 2011 Entertainment Weekly article, Schklair announced that he desired credit for directing The Room due to Wiseau becoming too engrossed with his acting duties to direct the film properly. Schklair told EW that Wiseau asked him to 'tell the actors what to do' and 'yell Action' and 'Cut' and tell the cameraman what shots to get.' This story is corroborated by one of the film's actors (who requested anonymity) and by Sestero in The Disaster Artist.
Schklair left the production before the end of principal photography in favor of the short film Jumbo Girl due to that project being shot by Janusz Kami≈Ñski.

Wiseau refused to give up the director title, even when Schklair took charge of numerous sequences in which Wiseau found himself unable to remember lines or adequately interact with the rest of the cast.
